creator: sysadmin@sunet.com.au
text:
This is a feature request instead of a bug report.  I'd like to have more 
configurable ServerTokens options.  Eg. mine says something like:
Server: Apache/1.3.22 (Unix)  (Red-Hat/Linux) mod_ssl/2.8.5 OpenSSL/0.9.6b 
PHP/4.0.6

I'd like it to say
Server: Apache/1.3 mod_ssl/2.8 OpenSSL/0.9 PHP/4.0

My suggestion is the following system:
ProductOnly
MajorVersion (+= ProductOnly)
MinorVersion (+= MajorVersion)
ReleaseNo (+= Minorversion)
OSGeneral (= Unix in my case)
OSSpecific (= Red-Hat/Linux in my case: += OSGeneral)

So then my settings would be MinorVersion, and Full would be equivalent to 
ReleaseNo OSSpecific.

Anyway, I hope this is a useful and clearly explained idea.  

Thanks all,

creator: holger.manthey@bertelsmann.de
text:
I have a very similar feature request. It is very useful to have ServerTokens on
a  directory context level. So we can use minimal Tokens for the world and full
a local access for version management.

I don't think that this would be very easy to do 
for a couple of reasons.

1. the 'redhat' thing is actually a hack/patch to the code by redhat
2. we (apache core) have zero control over what the module developers add to the 
   server tokens, at the moment they are doing it modulename/version but there is
   nothing saying that they have to, (eg.. mod_ssl actually adds the mod_ssl tag as 
   well as the openssl)

The -MinorVersion thing I think is good idea (so that is says Apache/2.0) I'll
see if I can get that into 2.0.41.

but please remember that most recent kidde hacks are blind, and don't look at
the server header at all, so playing with it won't stop them
